article.title: Immunological and hematological outcomes following protracted low dose/low dose rate ionizing radiation and simulated microgravity
article.abstract: Using a ground-based model to simulate spaceflight [21-days of single-housed, hindlimb unloading (HLU) combined with continuous low-dose gamma irradiation (LDR, total dose of 0.04 Gy)], an in-depth survey of the immune and hematological systems of mice at 7-days post-exposure was performed.

sections.introduction: While the majority of spaceflight studies focus on the physiological responses during or immediately after flight, readaptation to nominal gravitational environments is also an important factor in astronaut health.
sections.methods: Six-month-old, female C57BL/6J mice (Jackson Laboratory) were acclimatized in standard habitats at 20 Â°C with a 12 h:12 h light:dark cycle for 7 days.
sections.results: Principal component analysis (PCA) plots were generated with each cohort (Fig. 1A). Venn diagrams revealed no overlap of downregulated (Fig. 1B) nor upregulated (Fig. 1C) DEG.
sections.discussion: Recovery post-spaceflight is systemically taxing and often leaves a lasting impression on human health.

experimental_factors.treatment: hindlimb unloading, low-dose irradiation, simulated microgravity

article.insights_summary: This study revealed differential immune and hematological outcomes 1-week post-simulated spaceflight conditions, suggesting recovery from spaceflight is an unremitting process.
article.acknowledgments: We would like to thank the NASA GeneLab Analysis Working Group for helpful discussions.
